narratives.Foundational: ITSM processes are inconsistent or informal. Core practices such as incident, change, and service catalog management require structured definition and adoption.
narratives.Developing: ITSM processes exist but lack consistency or maturity. Improvements are needed in documentation, governance, and service quality measurement.
narratives.Established: ITSM practices are mature and well-governed. Opportunities remain in automation, optimisation, and proactive service management.
narratives.Advanced: ITSM is highly mature with strong governance, automation, and continuous improvement embedded across the service lifecycle.

Foundational: Document core ITSM processes for incident, request, change, and escalation.
Create a foundational service catalog and publish it for users.
Introduce basic SLAs and begin tracking performance.
Developing: Strengthen governance around change and escalation processes.
Expand your knowledge base with up-to-date, searchable documentation.
Improve SLA tracking and introduce regular service performance reviews.
Established: Automate routine workflows in ITSM tooling (assignments, approvals, categorisation).
Enhance the self-service portal to reduce manual workload.
Expand CSI practices into monthly operational rhythms.
Advanced: Leverage predictive analytics for incident trends and service optimisation.
Automate service onboarding, lifecycle tasks, and knowledge creation.
Integrate ITSM data into cross-functional business dashboards for executive reporting.

narratives.Foundational: Cyber controls are inconsistent or missing across identity, devices, access, and recovery. The environment is highly vulnerable to common attacks, and several Essential 8 baseline requirements are not met.
narratives.Developing: Some cyber controls exist, but enforcement is uneven or incomplete. Key areas such as MFA, patching, logging, or backup testing require improvement to meet Essential 8 and SMB1001 expectations.
narratives.Established: Core cyber controls are generally strong, with good coverage across identity, endpoints, access, and recovery. Remaining work focuses on consistency, automation, and deeper alignment with SMB1001 and ISO.
narratives.Advanced: Cyber maturity is high, with strong alignment to Essential 8, ISO 27001, and SMB1001. The environment demonstrates proactive monitoring, continuous improvement, and strong operational cyber practices.

Foundational: Implement MFA for all staff and administrators and enforce it consistently.
Deploy endpoint protection across all devices, including laptops, servers, and workstations.
Establish reliable, secure backups and test recovery regularly.
Introduce structured patching and vulnerability remediation cycles.
Developing: Fully enforce MFA for all privileged accounts.
Expand endpoint protection enforcement to any uncovered devices.
Increase the frequency and reliability of backup testing.
Formalise patching cycles to reduce inconsistent remediation.
Established: Align cyber controls with SMB1001 and Essential 8 Level 2 requirements.
Develop formal evidence collections for audits and client assurance.
Expand monitoring and logging to full coverage for all critical systems.
Automate alerting thresholds and response workflows.
Advanced: Introduce continuous threat hunting and advanced analytics.
Embed cyber maturity reviews into quarterly operational cadence.
Optimise automation for identity lifecycle, endpoint compliance, and log analysis.
Expand audit-readiness to include ISO 27001 certification traceability.

narratives.Foundational: Business processes are informal or inconsistent, with limited documentation and minimal automation.
narratives.Developing: Processes show structure but lack maturity, with inconsistent automation or unclear integration.
narratives.Established: Processes are well-documented and increasingly automated, with reliable workflow consistency.
narratives.Advanced: Business processes are optimisation-focused with strong automation, metrics, and cross-team clarity.

Foundational: Document core business processes and standard operating procedures.
Identify manual processes with the highest time impact.
Introduce foundational workflow tools for simple automation.
Developing: Expand automation to multi-step workflows and common approvals.
Improve data flow between systems by aligning integration points.
Update training materials to reflect new processes.
Established: Introduce advanced workflow automation across departments.
Implement monitoring dashboards to track process performance.
Standardise integration patterns across business applications.
Advanced: Apply predictive analytics to identify process optimisation opportunities.
Align business processes to measurable strategic outcomes.
Introduce adaptive workflows and continuous improvement cycles.

narratives.Foundational: Operational practices are mostly reactive with limited monitoring, automation, or governance.
narratives.Developing: Some operational structure is emerging, but automation and consistency need improvement.
narratives.Established: Operational practices are consistent, automated, and regularly reviewed.
narratives.Advanced: Operational excellence is proactive and data-driven with automation and intelligent tooling embedded across workflows.

Foundational: Establish core monitoring and alerting for critical systems.
Document basic operating procedures for routine tasks.
Identify high-frequency manual tasks suitable for automation.
Developing: Expand monitoring coverage and establish performance baselines.
Automate multi-step operational tasks such as provisioning and checks.
Introduce intelligent rules or lightweight AI features to reduce manual workload.
Established: Implement event correlation and automated RCA insights.
Optimise automation coverage and remove remaining manual steps.
Enhance governance cadence with measurable outcomes.
Advanced: Introduce predictive analytics for outage prevention.
Implement fully automated remediation scripts for common issues.
Align operational excellence KPIs with strategic business outcomes.

narratives.Foundational: Technical foundations such as identity, device management, networks, and DR require significant uplift.
narratives.Developing: Some technical foundations are in place but need consistency, standardisation, and improved governance.
narratives.Established: Technical foundations are strong with sound identity, device, network, and platform governance.
narratives.Advanced: Technical capabilities are robust, automated, and aligned with leading engineering and platform practices.

Foundational: Introduce strong identity lifecycle management with enforced access controls.
Deploy central device management and enforce security baselines.
Document network segmentation strategy and begin implementing modern controls.
Developing: Strengthen cloud readiness planning across applications and infrastructure.
Improve platform governance, including admin roles and lifecycle procedures.
Enhance backup and DR testing to meet RTO/RPO targets.
Established: Expand observability and telemetry across all core systems.
Optimise network segmentation and strengthen micro-segmentation.
Formalise governance processes for cross-platform lifecycle activities.
Advanced: Introduce engineering automation for platform updates and compliance checks.
Deploy advanced telemetry and predictive performance analytics.
Integrate technical metrics into business reporting dashboards.
